paragraphs.body: Anyone who is following the Fanon Awards and who looks at recent wiki activity is likely to know the category already.  If they see a comment for “Wordbender,” they do know that it is not for Best Male Supporting Character.  Either a majority or a minority is still a portion, and seeing the vote in recent activity directly shows it the entirety of the time.  What I meant by your calculations being off is somehow stating a partial amount being greater than whole, where even if it was the whole amount, it would be equal to, not greater.  If it’s any less than whole, it’s less, as is the case here.

paragraphs.body: In terms of the internet, even one extra click means something significant.  A few extra clicks or typing out an extra template is still easy, but still not as easy as the reply-type-post method.  Also, while this extra time is small for each individual category, it’s greater if one multiplies it by 15-20 to account for how many categories there are in the awards.

paragraphs.body: Hey, remember the time I said “I’m so proud of the way that the Fanon Awards do there voting that I would desist from changing it even if it were valuable to do so.”  You don’t?  That’s because probably I never did.  It was your own negative assumption that said that.

paragraphs.body: So basically, you concede the point that the Fanon Awards system has the advantage with the comment itself, but you claim that the User Awards have the advantage because of the comments being pushed down.  This point is irrelevant when there are links to the comment threads on the page itself, just like the User Awards has links to the list of categories and then to the pages (a two-step link, I might add, not a one-step link, which adds yet another click.)  Your other claimed advantage is “overview”, but overview has not been an issue.  The other councilors, myself, and even some non-councilors have helped out, and I don’t consider it a nuisance.  I even enjoy it.  So, that point is moot as well.

paragraphs.body: The change in Fanon Awards activity and liveliness has a lot to do with the voting system.  Sure, the mindset of the community is what sparks the atmosphere that the awards are a part of, but with the community being a constant presence, the format of the awards has changed and is therefore the "test subject."  During the Fourth Fanon Awards last Summer, the canon side was still much more in the spotlight.  With so much time in between seasons, this year the awards are more active than the Third Awards, but that doesn’t explain why the Fourth Awards were also much more active than the Third Awards.  You can call my argument “void of credibility” all you want, but the fact is the only point still standing is on my argument and all the points of your argument are either untrue, or hypothetical and irrelevant. --AvatarRokus Ghost (Message me • Read my fanon)   22:54, August 26, 2013 (UTC)
